questions.answer_description:
Scenario: Regional managers require a visual to analyze weekly sales and returns.
To relate the two tables we need a common column.
questions.question_text:
You need to create a relationship between the Weekly_Returns table and the Date table to meet the reporting requirements of the regional managers.
What should you do?

comments.content: They can't be related on the week columns because in the Date table a week might have two values if it is included in two months (e.g. week 13 in 2021 goes from Mar 29th to Apr 4th) and the relationship will assign the value twice
I totally agree.
It is true, it would be the perfect solution. If there is not the perfect solution, you have to choose the less wrong solution and it is B.

That would be a many-to-many relationship.
* Date/week has the same item 7 times a week. From February 7th 2022 to February 13th 2022 we are in the same week
* Weekly_Returns/week_id is repeated as many times as regions (sales_regions_id) exist. 

I am not absolutely sure how would that work because the description says that there are many data sources and many-to-many relationships have some limitations if some of the tables come from DirectQuery sources.
So, I would vote "B" as correct answer

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/transform-model/desktop-many-to-many-relationships

discussion.content:
In the environment eplaination is written "The week column in the Date table and the week_id column in the Weekly_Returns table have a format of yyyyww."
So I assume that missing answer is to setup reletionship between above columns
B is correct

comments.content: Is impossible, because on Weekly_Returns, data is groped by region_id.

discussion.content: Can we expect these questions in the exam? can someone who took the exam recently confirm, please?
There should be an option for non of the above.
on exam 3/1/2022

B is correct.
We can't create a 1:* relationship between Date and weekly_return, because in Date table could be more than one row for a week.(e.g for 2 different Date in same week, then they have same week)

The missing answer should be to create a relationship between Weekly_Return table and Date table because The week column in the Date table and the week_id column in the Weekly_Returns table have a format of yyyyww. so no need to do what answer B is suggesting.

comments.content: This came in my Exam 16/10 and i went for B

discussion.content:
If many records in Weekly_Returns table have same yyyyww values, the value of new calculated column date_id have same value. For example you return $3000 to Region A on 202102, you also return $2000 to Region B on 202102. After calculation, the date_id of these 2 records are all equal to 20210104.

How to transfer yyyyww to yyyymmdd by calculation?

comments.content: I got this too, but I don’t understand why everyone here is saying the opposite?
"The week column in the Date table and the week_id column in the Weekly_Returns table have a format of yyyyww." there is no mention of relationship between them, only them being the same

discussion.content: The argument for the solution doesn't make sense. There is already a relationship between Weekly_returns and Date on date[Week] and Weekly_Returns[Week_ID] as noted.

comments.content:
“ The week column in the Date table and the week_id column in the Weekly_Returns table have a format of yyyyww.”
Why are you saying there’s no relation?

discussion.content: B is the correct answer , we can use RELATED because no column in common between the two table and C is completely false

RELATED() requires relationship between 2 queries. So A can not be correct. If you look at Date table and Weekly returns table, relationship type can not be M2M, So C is as well incorrect. We are left with B, its doable but not a best way. It will need effort.

A is correct (but not the best option as creating a measure is a more preferable option here). Sales relates to Date as n - 1 (sales_date_id - date_id) and Date relates to Weekly_Returns as n - 1 (week - week_id). That means Sales relates to Weekly_Returns as n - 1 also and we can add Weekly return amount to Sales by using the RELATED func

Is there any simple way to get yyyymmdd from yyyyww?
Merge Weekly_Returns with Date on yyyyww and get the earliest date from particular week?

i think it's A 
Here we have :The week column in the Date table and the week_id column in the Weekly_Returns table have a format of yyyyww
the two columns have also the same type ( same type and same values)

comments.content:
Agree, there should be an option D
But B can work as well
correction: B can return correct results after aggregation with weekly Sales. It's not the best modeling approach but still works. C is far from getting the right results. So the answer is B

discussion.content:
A: incorrect - RELATED DAX function requires a relationship between 2 tables, while we can't build a relationship between sales (daily) & returns (weekly)
B: incorrect - This procedure will change weekly data in returns to daily, and eventually will end up incorrect results after being aggregated to weekly
C: unnecessary & incomplete procedures, hardly to be correct - suppose the relationship between new Date table & Weekly_Returns is built correctly based on week & week_id, and 1 direction from Returns to new Date, but the new Date table is not linked to Sales, it doesn't help with the relationship with Returns & Sales. You still need to link the new Date table with Sales. Also there's no need to create a new Date table as there is one already, it's easier to link Sales & Date (on date_id), Date & Returns (week).

It looks like there is a 'D' option missing here. If not then C, at least it doesn't return incorrect results

choices.B: In the Weekly_Returns table, create a new calculated column named date_id in a format of yyyymmdd and use the calculated column to create a relationship to the Date table.
choices.C: Create a new table based on the Date table where date_id is unique, and then create a many-to-many relationship to Weekly_Return.
choices.A: Add the Weekly_Returns data to the Sales table by using RELATED DAX functions.

questions.question_text:
You need to create relationships to meet the reporting requirements of the customer service department.
What should you create?

discussion.content: they fixed the answer few days ago, now is A!

comments.content: Is correcto, the answer is A

I agree. Problem is that D could only be correct if it also specified making a DAX measure using userelationship() and specifying date_id to sales_date_id as 1:* (not vice versa). Would be much better ito performance, but no such requirement is specified.
I share the same notion.. You only need to have on active relationship anyway. You can use the said function.
There are two ways to relate additional relationship in the same table: Use USERELATIONSHIP or create an additional date table.

I agree that the answer should be C. You can have 2 relationships set up for the sales and date tables, only one can be active, and you can turn the appropriate relationship on at will using DAX. No need to clutter the model with extra tables and columns.
I agree with you.. this is what I would have done in a real life scenario. but giving the question scope. A is the best answer as inactive relationships are not an option.

discussion.content:
In my opinion, USERELATIONSHIP() can be used here for the inactive relationship between Sales_ship_date_id and Date_id. No need to create a new table.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/userelationship-function-dax
If I'm wrong, please correct me.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
I got it on my exam 03/17/2022. 90-95% questions were from here. 61 questions in 100 min. All 3 case studies that appeared in exam, where from here.

comments.content: Answered: A

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct answer. there are 2 ways to solve the problem: Role-playing dimension, and UseRelationship method. Check this link for explanation https://radacad.com/userelationship-or-role-playing-dimension-dealing-with-inactive-relationships-in-power-bi

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A
Sales table to filtered by newly created Shipdate table and existed Date table

on exam - Nov 11, 2021. 
my answer:
an additional date table named ShipDate, a one-to-many relationship from Date[date_id] to Sales[Sales_date_id], and a one-to-many relationship from ShipDate[date_id] to Sales[sales_ship_date_id]
On exam 10/14/21

comments.content: Read, you create ShipDate yourself

discussion.content: A and B are not possible: ShipDate[date_id] doesn't excist... And you can't connect week and date_id in C. So D is left.

the question is what to CREATE. The answer is D. a one-to-many relationship from Sales[sales_date_id] to Date[date_id] and a one-to-many relationship from Sales[sales_ship_date_id] to Date[date_id] .
Note: 1-to-many is the type of the relationship, not the direction.

Think its A. Theres two topics here:

1. Role playing dimensions. Have 2 date tables that can be filtered indep.
2. Use relationship

Answer: E

Explanation:

Scenario: The customer service department requires a visual that can be filtered by both sales month and ship month independently.

Reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/transform-model/desktop-relationships-understand
A is the correct answer , one to many relationship

For my A. an additional date table named ShipDate, a one-to-many relationship from Date[sales_date_id] to Sales[date_id], and a one-to-many relationship from ShipDate[sales_ship_date_id] to Sales[date_id] is the best option in fact is the best practice for these cases

Honestly, I think none of the answers are correct: 

1) Creating a new date table is a bad solution as you bloat up the data model. That rules out A and B. 

2) Working with a second (inactive) relation between the sales and date table is the way to go, however both C and D don't work out either since D mixes up the direction of the relationships, and C wants to connect date_id and week_id, which won't work.

This question appears a few pages earlier, too, and there are different answering options. The right is included in that version. 

Any thoughts? I'm happy to be convinced otherwise.

comments.content:
Out of the options given, A is the only one that would work, but if they just phrased it a bit differently, D would be correct and in a real world solution, that is what you'd use. 
You'd have 2 relationships from the sales table to the Date table (one would be inactive). To use the inactive one, you'd use the USERELATIONSHIP function in your DAX. The only reason it's not correct is because the way they wrote the many-to-one part is the wrong way around.

Date tables itself aren't big, eventually relationships may take more space when on many side of one-to-many relationship you have millions of rows.
There is nothing about not increasing the size of the model, so still A is valid in this case.

discussion.content: A is the correct answers. Since, role-playing dimension is one of the solution to solve active and inactive problem. In addition, relationship is also correct in choice A.
E . a one-to-many relationship from Date[date_id] to Sales[sales_date_id] and another one-to-many relationship from Date[date_id] to Sales[sales_ship_date_id] is missing from choice.
Should be A, but with correction on the typo, the relatioship should be Date[date_id] one-to-many to Sales[sales_date_id], ShipDate[date_id] one-to-many to Sales[sales_ship_date_id].

comments.content: one-to-many relationship is the same as many-to-one rel.

discussion.content: The column names are not correct in Answer A!

comments.content: D might be, but the one-to-many is wrong should be many-to-one

discussion.content:

one-to-many relationship from ShipDate[date_id] to Sales[ship_sales_date_id]

otherwise A is not correct.
Yes A is the ans

in A the columns are mixed up: there is no [sales_date_id] column in the Date table and no [date_id] column in the sales table. So, it cannot be A.
I would go for B, although I don´t see why many-to-many relationships are necessary.
Best answer would be mix: B with one-to-many relationships.

I'm wondering if there is a typo on the page. You are correct Ian7687, but I think like b23jk91 said, there no column [sales_date_id].

D is the correct choice

This question should replace 8.3 and I agree with the answer. although I am not sure if you need an additional date table

I think its B. The relations in A make no sense

I think A makes perfect sense. 
Adding Ship Table will give the customer service department more insight on possible delivery dates when customers call in.
The approach with A is correct, but no relationship is using the ship_date_id column.
An additional date table is required because of the report requirement of filtered by both sales month and ship month independently so need 2 active relationships?

choices.C: a one-to-many relationship from Date[date_id] to Sales[sales_date_id] and another one-to-many relationship from Date[date_id] to Weekly_Returns[week_id]
choices.A: an additional date table named ShipDate, a one-to-many relationship from Date[date_id] to Sales[Sales_date_id], and a one-to-many relationship from ShipDate[date_id] to Sales[sales_ship_date_id]
choices.B: an additional date table named ShipDate, a many-to-many relationship from Sales[sales_date_id] to Date[date_id], and a many-to-many relationship from Sales[sales_ship_date_id] to ShipDate[date_id]
choices.D: a one-to-many relationship from Sales[sales_date_id] to Date[date_id] and a one-to-many relationship from Sales[sales_ship_date_id] to Date[date_id]

discussion.content:
Ans - CALCULATE ( SUM( BalanceSheet [BalanceAmount] ), LASTDATE( 'Date'[Date] ) )
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/create-measures-dax-power-bi/5-semi-additive-measures

comments.content: We have to add all months in a quarter as the each month shows amounts for that month alone, thus a sum of all months is needed and not just Incremental addition. A should be the answer.
It's not the case. The amount is a balance that take in consideration the movements of each month, but already aggregated.

be careful read the following action requirements " At least one of the balance sheet reports in the quarterly reporting package must show the ending balances for the quarter, as well as for the previous quarter." so i think that answer A is the right one

discussion.content:
Ans. is A.
At least one of the balance sheet reports in the quarterly reporting package must show the ending balances for the quarter, as well as for the previous quarter.

comments.content: Incorrect. A will sum the balances across all months in the current quarter to date, which is not how balance sheets are designed to work. A balance sheet is a position at a moment in time, so you need to look for the latest one(s) only to get the position in the current quarter. Answer B is correct.
That is correct, if you ues the DatesQTD fuction as a filter, the calculation fuction is going to sum up all the date of balance included in the range of dates.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Quarterly reporting of balance sheet accounts should refer to the value of the last month of the quarter. So it should use semi-additive measure

Selected Answer: B
B is correct answer
I got it on my exam 03/17/2022. 90-95% questions were from here. 61 questions in 100 min. All 3 case studies that appeared in exam, where from here.

comments.content: Answered: B

discussion.content:
I understand that SUM is the perfect function combined with LASTDATE, but I have a problem with the sign. The balance is showing two asset accounts and one liability account. We can't make the direct sum of things that are the opposite.
The assets minus liabilities and net worth are always equal to zero, but the example does not show all the accounts.

Some good question would be:
1* which is the Balance Amount for the assets every month, quarter, etc.? In this case we should sum only the asset accounts (cash and inventories)
2* which is the working capital? This are short term assets minus short term liabilities. But there are two problems. They are giving us long-term liabilities, not short-term ones. And we need to change the sign before summing.

I think the answer should be 
D. CALCULATE ( MAX( BalanceSheet[BalanceAmount] ), LASTDATE( 'Date' [Date] ) )
In exam

comments.content: What was your answer for this and Did you pass ?

discussion.content: DATESQTD is going to return multiple dates and you don't want to sum all of those dates b/c the value you have for each date is the balance on that date, so it's LASTDATE (IMO).

A: 
You must not sum balance values. They are already sums. Every following balance value includes the previous values. 
DATESQTD: Delivers a table of dates including every (used) date of the current quarter of the filter context. -> sums every monthly balance value of a quarter -> bad
LASTDATE: Delivers a table of exactly one date. The last (used) date in the filter context. -> sums the last balance value a quarter -> nice

At least one of the balance sheet reports in the quarterly reporting package must show the ending balances for the quarter, as well as for the previous quarter. - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/datesqtd-function-dax#example

on exam - Nov 11, 2021. 
my answer:
CALCULATE ( SUM( BalanceSheet [BalanceAmount] ), DATESQTD( 'Date'[Date] ) )
On exam 10/14/21
https://community.powerbi.com/t5/Desktop/Power-Pivot-DAX-Balance-sheet-averages/td-p/473904
I am very confused - is there even any relationship that has been established between the balance sheet table and the date table??

comments.content: I have same question. No date column in balance sheet table. How it link with data table to get last date? No description in the question to explain it.
Read this line in the question "You plan to relate the balance sheet to a standard date table in Power BI in a many-to-one relationship based on the last day of the month. "
Feel that Sum is to get total balance from different AccountCategorys.

discussion.content: What is the purpose of using the SUM function here?
Answer is B. Semi-additive calculations (i.e. balance at end of month) often use LASTDATE Functions.
It's B. It's a semi-additive measure. You want to be able to sum up all the accounts of one account category, thus SUM, but you only want to include the latest balance of each quarter, thus LASTDATE.

The selected answer is sort of right.
Correct would be something like:
Calculate'BalanceSheet'[BalanceAmount], DATESQTD(Date[Date]))

Have a go at dax.guide 
https://dax.do/ztDogaRP8jEE7c/

comments.content: answer is A*

discussion.content:
answer is B ,DATESQTD returns the dates from the first day of the currently selected
-- quarter to the last date visible in the filter context.

I'll go for B. Lhouss's recommendation makes it clear.

"The balance of a quarter is not the sum of individual monthly balances. Instead, the measure should report the last balance of the quarter.“

Answer A

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/datesqtd-function-dax

"
Example
The following sample formula creates a measure that calculates the 'Quarterly Running Total' of Internet Sales.

DAX
= CALCULATE(SUM(InternetSales_USD[SalesAmount_USD]), DATESQTD(DateTime[DateKey])) 
"

First things first..
Balance sheet is a snapshot in time. It can't be simply summed. 
Example Inventory:
In january i had 10 apples, in february i had 5 apples, in march i had 15 apples.
If i want quarterly report for inventory balance i can't sum january + february + march. That number (10 + 5 + 15 wouldn't mean anything).
If looking at day by day changes, these are actual changes, not absolute amounts.
So if i want to see inventory for 1st quarter, i will look at last day of march to get it.

DATESQTD takes all days in quarter and does sum - this is ok for sales measure, but not for ending balance.
More info: https://www.daxpatterns.com/semi-additive-calculations/

comments.content:
I had no idea what ending balance was before reading this question - so I googled the definition and went for. This was the definition I got: 
"The ending balance is the net residual balance in an account. It is usually measured at the end of a reporting period, as part of the closing process. An ending balance is derived by adding up the transaction totals in an account and then adding this total to the beginning balance"

discussion.content: The way I understand every month balance show the balance endofmonth-startofmonth so IF you add them up you get difference of endofqrt-staofqrt, I would go for A.
A is a running total, and B is a semiaditive measure. So I go for the answer B (you only add the facts related to the last date)

comments.content: it says to get the ending balance, so go for last date is correct

discussion.content: trick question it should be the last date function but the reports must be shown in quarterly form. weird. I would go with A

you have to read the case study well,

"The board must be able to get the following information from the QUARTERLY reports:"
Ending balances for each account
A comparison of quarterly revenue versus the same QUARTER during the prior year

Therefore the answer is A.

comments.content:
Balance Sheet Data -
The balance sheet data is imported with final balances for each account per month

Therefore we must add the balances per month, Answer A. function DATESQTD
No need to calculate the SUM of months, only last amount on last day of quarter. this BALANCE sheet

the balance amount column is not cumulative, for example,
BalanceSheet (ACcount) = inventories
for Mount = 1 ****** BalanceAmount = 65,998
Mount = 2 ********** BalanceAmount = 5,845 (it is less than the previous month, it is not cumulative)
Mount = 3 ********* Lever Mount 4,855 (same)

Therefore the BalanceAmount for inventories = 76,698 (quarter)

Using, DATESQTD gives that amount
and using LASTDATE, it would give the last date that would be = 4,855

So I still think the answer is A

discussion.content:
Answer is A and explanation is good to know :
"At least one of the balance sheet reports in the quarterly reporting package must show the ending balances for the quarter, as well as for the previous quarter."
Since w talk about quater it should be DATESQTD and then we can compare Quarters

A is correct.
We need to aggregate balance sheet to have the quarterly ending.

comments.content:
Correct answer is B.
My bad, please don't consider my last coment.
Good reference : https://www.sqlbi.com/articles/semi-additive-measures-in-dax/

discussion.content:
ok, here we go, as a CPA candidate who already passed all 4 sections of the CPA exams, I'm so responsible to tell that no way it would be A/B/C, becoz BS account's # is an ending balance, it's an accumulative account showing a status at a specific moment in time.
Link: https://scalefactor.com/ask-the-experts/balance-sheet-vs-income-statement/#:~:text=Timing%3A%20The%20balance%20sheet%20shows,for%20a%20period%20of%20time.&text=The%20income%20statement%20is%20used,financial%20issues%20that%20need%20correcting.

must be D, we only get the latest date and max amount# (a specific moment + accumulative)

B - CALCULATE ( SUM( BalanceSheet [BalanceAmount] ), LASTDATE( 'Date'[Date] ) ) is Correct 
" LASTDate " Returns the last date in the current context for the specified column of dates.
so this DAX will return the Ending Balance in the Total sheet 
in the other hand, " DATESQTD " calculates the 'Quarterly Running Total' of Balance .

""The balance sheet data is imported with final balances for each account per month in the format shown in the following table."""

“”Report Requirements -
You plan to relate the balance sheet to a standard date table in Power BI in a many-to-one relationship based on the last day of the month. At least one of the balance sheet reports in the quarterly reporting package must show the ending balances for the quarter, as well as for the previous quarter.””


The balance sheet is monthly but you need to create a report that shows it quarterly.


• A. CALCULATE ( SUM( BalanceSheet [BalanceAmount] ), DATESQTD( 'Date'[Date] ) )

if it is to display the balance by quarter, I would use the "DATESQTD" function.

comments.content: As explained in other comments, DATESQTD yields ALL the dates in the Quarter and NOT just the Last Date available. The correct approach for a balance sheet, which resembles time snapshots, and works in a semi-additive fashion for Date, is to grab ONE specific Point-in-time and then process the total balance with SUM . Correct answer is B.

discussion.content:
Microsoft website says: 
"The following sample formula creates a measure that calculates the 'Quarterly Running Total' of Internet Sales."
= CALCULATE(SUM(InternetSales_USD[SalesAmount_USD]), DATESQTD(DateTime[DateKey]))

The above formulae is similar to the one mentioned in the question and this gives the running total, but we dont need running total, we need the balances at the end of the quarter.
So B seems to be the correct Answer.

comments.content: i think it's a coincidence A&B are both right because the data given happened to be within quarter Q1

discussion.content:
I tested the answers by importing the table and create some measures with the given dax formulas.
A en B both give the right answer, 75351. Answer D didn't, it just returned the highest amount 50.207

B and D will product the same result, because balance is not additive , it's value on that particular day. it can not be A because it will SUM all values from first of qtr to current date, it should be one of B or D.
Why not B ?

Since we are talking about amount answer A seems correct, if we are talking about inventory/stock, instead of sum all month we want the last position value and for that case option B should be the answer.

comments.content: A Balance Sheet is a picture of the Company at a given Date (Quarter), so the response is B

In a balance sheet that is what you're talking about. You are talking about cash in a bank, inventory on hand, how much do you owe to your suppliers at that moment. You can't sum the status of each month. As VR1 said, they are semi additive measures.

discussion.content: answer B

questions.question_text: Which DAX expression should you use to get the ending balances in the balance sheet reports?
questions.answer_description:
Scenario: At least one of the balance sheet reports in the quarterly reporting package must show the ending balances for the quarter, as well as for the previous quarter.
DATESQTD returns a table that contains a column of the dates for the quarter to date, in the current context.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/datesqtd-function-dax

Box 1: A DAX Calculated measure -
Box 2: Date.EndofQuarter(#date([Year],[Mont],1))
ENDOFQUARTER returns the last date of the quarter in the current context for the specified column of dates.
The following sample formula creates a measure that returns the end of the quarter, for the current context.
= ENDOFQUARTER(DateTime[DateKey])
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/endofquarter-function-dax
Model the Data

comments.content: Thats is right bro!
Supported

Agree, see reference 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powerquery-m/date-endofmonth

discussion.content:
Type of calculation - M Custom Column
Formula - Date.EndOfMonth
C and A
It must be end of month, so Formula must include Endofmonth. There is only one Endofmonth formula which is a M formula, so it has to be an M custom column.

comments.content: Answered: M custom and EndOfMonth

discussion.content: answer is correct

According to the answer provided by my Power BI instructor in Taiwan, Linda Wu（吳翠鳳）, the answer must be：

 An M custom column
 Date.EndOfMonth(#date([Year], [Month], 1))

comments.content: Linda Wu rules. Send her my greetings

discussion.content: C & A. The balancesheet contains data for every month, it is not a quarterly fact
The reports are quarterly not monthly. I think the given answer works.

comments.content: are you sure on this as many evidence above indicates M and end ofMonth
The question specifically asks for end of month. The only formula that makes sense is the M syntax (Date.EndOfMonth), and thus the method is M. VR1's first response is correct IMO.

Code FYI.

let
 Source = Excel.CurrentWorkbook(){[Name="DateYearQ"]}[Content],
 #"Changed Type" = Table.TransformColumnTypes(Source,{{"Month", Int64.Type}, {"Year", Int64.Type}}),
 #"Added Custom" = Table.AddColumn(#"Changed Type", "Custom", each Date.EndOfMonth(#date([Year], [Month], 1))),
 #"Changed Type1" = Table.TransformColumnTypes(#"Added Custom",{{"Custom", type date}})
in
 #"Changed Type1"

discussion.content:
Tested. 3/1
M custom column + Date.EndOfMonth(#date([Year], [Month], 1))

"You need to calculate the last day of the month in the balance sheet data"

Answer: M and Date.EndofMonth()

Type of calculation - M Custom Column
Formula - Date.EndOfMonth
For those who hesitated on DAX function, the ENDOFQUARTER returns the last date of the quarter, and the question asks you to calculate the last date of Month...

Type of calculation - M Custom Column
Formula - Date.EndOfMonth

Date.EndOfQuarter - PowerQuery M 
Date.EndOfMonth - PowerQuery M
ENDOFQUARTER function (DAX)
A - a column , C - this is dax function

IT MUST BE A COLUMN, NOT A MEASURE, BECAUSE WE NEED IT FOR A RELATIONSHIP. AND THE m-CODE DOES NOT HAVE ENOUGH FUNCTIONS RELATED TO THE DATE DATA TYPE, HENCE i CHOOSE "DAX CLCULATED COLUMN"
FOR THE FORMULA, IT MUST BE "DATE.END OF MONTH" BECAUSE THE BALANCE SHEET HAS A SINGLE ROW FOR EVERY MONTH.

comments.content:
So you chose a DAX Calculated Column and use M code to calculate that column?
It is indeed Date.Endofmonth but it can only be used in power query therefore M column.

But totally agree about the measure being out of the question.

discussion.content: Provided answer is correct
it can NOT be custom column, because custom column is useless for aggregate functions on multiple rows, custome column is useful to create calculated value across multiple cols within same row.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You need to calculate the last day of the month in the balance sheet data to ensure that you can relate the balance sheet data to the Date table.
Which type of calculation and which formula should you use? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
